img.alt: A restored F4U-4 Corsair in Korean War-ear U.S. Marine Corps markings

div.p: The Chance Vought F4U Corsair was a carrier-capable fighter aircraft that saw service primarily in World War II and the Korean War. Demand for the aircraft soon overwhelmed Vought's manufacturing capability, resulting in production by Goodyear and Brewster: Goodyear-built Corsairs were designated FG and Brewster-built aircraft F3A. From the first prototype delivery to the U.S. Navy in 1940, to final delivery in 1953 to the French, 12,571 F4U Corsairs were manufactured by Vought,[1] in 16 separate models, in the longest production run of any piston-engined fighter in U.S. history (1942â€“53).

table.caption: Operational History of the F4U Corsair

div.p: The F4U Corsair produces multiple aces 5 victories against ennemies or more.
The first ace was produced within the VMF-124 squadron. Second Lieutenant Kenneth A. Walsh racked up a total of 21 kills during World War II.

dl.dt: F4U-1 (Corsair MK I Fleet Air Arm)
dl.dd: The first production version of the corsair with the distinctive "bird cage" canopy and low seating position.
New canopy design, raised pilot seat. Moreover, it is the first "carrier capable" Corsair.
This was the designation for the Brewster-built F4U-1. Just over 700 were built due to poor production techniques.
Unofficial post-war designation used to identify F4U-1s modified for FAA use.
